blocks.name: rabdiophlem1
blocks.content: Lemma for arithmetic diophantine sets. Convert polynomial-ness of an expression into a constraint suitable for ~ ralimi . (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 10-Oct-2014.)

  mp2an(wss(co(cn0, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), co(cz, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0))), wcel(cz, universe), wss(cn0, cz))

  mzpf(cmpt(s0, co(cz, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), c1), co(nat1, cfz, c0))
  fmpt(s0, co(cz, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), c1, cz, cmpt(s0, co(cz, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), c1))
  eqid(cmpt(s0, co(cz, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), c1))
  ssralv(s0, co(cn0, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), co(cz, cmap, co(nat1, cfz, c0)), wcel(c1, cz))

blocks.name: nerabdioph
blocks.content: Diophantine set builder for inequality. This not quite trivial theorem touches on something important; Diophantine sets are not closed under negation, but they contain an important subclass that is, namely the recursive sets. With this theorem and De Morgan's laws, all quantifier-free formulas can be negated. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 11-Oct-2014.)
